awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Testing rules of life for developmental trade-offs in sensory and cognitive systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. Development involves growth of the body and differentiation into specialized tissues. In response to early-life stress, organisms - from plants to insects to mammals - face trade-offs between developmental speed and specialization. Maturing at a faster rate may help organisms escape environmental stress but creates trade-offs with other traits that are important for survival such as body size, limb formation, and immune-system function. This research explores how accelerated growth impacts neural and cognitive development, which is critical for animals to accurately respond to beneficial cues and threats in their environments. Since developmental pathways and decision-making brain regions are shared across vertebrates, the Fellow’s research will be a major step forward for identifying mechanisms that mediate trade-offs between growth and differentiation. The Fellow will develop new, web-based activities to distribute material to a diverse audience and work with Native American students to incorporate frog-centric narratives that lend cultural and historical relevance to lesson plans.
  
The Fellow will build networks across two research labs at Utah State University (USU) and the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign to examine if sensory and cognitive phenotypes in anurans are stable or flexible in response to accelerated development. The Fellow will manipulate developmental timing in three distantly-related species of anurans to assess trade-offs in morphology, locomotion, sensory perception, and cognition, and then link trade-offs to underlying neuromolecular mechanisms and gene-expression patterns. This research will reveal how developmental plasticity manifests across levels of biological organization, how these patterns evolve or are maintained across diverse taxa, and how these phenomena influence the resiliency of species and communities to ecosystem changes. An additional component of the project is expansion to northern Utah K-12 schools by the Froggers School Program which brings hands-on, question-based learning experiences to local classrooms. The Fellow will also partner with established programs that specialize in student retention, completion, and inclusion at USU by mentoring students in undergraduate-led research and outreach projects that match students’ career goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This two-year NSF project assessed how accelerated growth impacts neural and cognitive development, and aimed to identify shared mechanisms that mediate trade-offs between growth and differentiation across vertebrates. The PI worked across two research labs at Utah State University and the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign to examine if sensory and cognitive phenotypes in anurans are stable or flexible in response to accelerated development.

The PI reared five clutches of cane toads (Rhinella marina) and three clutches of wood frogs (Rana sylvatica) at two larval densities to induce variation in developmental rate and collected individual-level data during the larval stage and early juvenile stage, including survivorship, morphology and growth, behavior, sensory ability, endocrine patterns, cellular activity, and gene expression. This work is among the first in anurans to describe phenotypic plasticity that span levels of biological organization at multiple timepoints across developmental stages, which will provide a more fine-scale understanding of trait responses to developmental environments and consequences of those responses on later-life performance. Results from this project have been accepted for presentation at three scientific conferences and are currently under review for one publication. With this fellowship, the PI also co-authored a meta-analysis of metamorphic responses to developmental stressors in anurans, which was published in 2023, and co-authored a perspectives piece to encourage early-career researchers in organismal biology, which is currently in press. The PI will continue to disseminate results from this project in peer-reviewed publications (three in preparation for submission later this year with more planned for next year) and in scientific conferences upcoming over the next year (World Congress of Herpetology, Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology, and Animal Behavior). The robust dataset and samples collected by the PI across this fellowship forms a strong foundation for the PI, graduate, and undergraduate students in a tenure-track research program, for which the PI will be applying over the next year while continuing the research funded by this fellowship as a postdoc at Cornell University and an affiliate researcher at Utah State University.

In addition to the research activities described above, the PI co-lead diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives for the Biology department at Utah State University, developed a robust undergraduate mentoring program, and partnered with established programs to offer research opportunities that matched career goals and cultural identities of students. Over the course of two years, the PI mentored five paid undergraduate assistants with animal care and research activities (four identify as women, one identifies as Native American, and two are non-traditional students). Two of these mentees are pursuing graduate degrees in STEM, one is currently preparing for publication an independent research project she completed under guidance of the PI, and two are still undergraduates in STEM majors at Utah State University. In addition to these mentees, the PI co-mentored three students in the Native American Summer Mentorship Program at Utah State University across two summers, which provided a week-long experiential learning in which they assisted with animal care and collected their own data for a small project. The PI plans to build upon these initiatives over the next year and partner with two local nonprofit institutions (the Loveland Living Planet Aquarium and Stokes Nature Center) to develop educational content for their exhibits and programs, which not only serve K-12 students, but also the broader state-wide community.


Last Modified: 06/24/2024
Modified by: Sarah Mckay Strobel
